Detailed Description

The abstract base class for DB-backed model objects.

Project EmeRails - Codename Ocarina

© 2008 Claudio Procida http://www.emeraldion.it

Every object of a subclass of ActiveRecord are mapped 1:1 to records of a table in a relational Database. Naming conventions assume that if the ActiveRecord subclass is called MyProduct, database records are stored in a table called my_products. Conversely, if an object of another class is in a relation with your object, it is assumed that a foreign key called my_product_id exists in the other table. Of course this is overridable by setting explicitly $table_name and $foreign_key to a value of your choice.

Definition at line 23 of file base.php.

Member Function Documentation

ActiveRecord::ActiveRecord ( $  _values = NULL  ) 

Constructs and initializes an ActiveRecord object.

ActiveRecord Due to the lack of a static class initialization method, the default constructor is in charge of gathering information about the bound table columns the first time an object is created. Subsequent creations will use the values stored in static class variables. Subclassers don't need to override the constructor. They can in turn override the init method in order to perform custom initialization.

Parameters:
values Column values to initialize the object.

ActiveRecord::get_table_name (  )  [private]

Returns the name of the table bound to this class.

This method returns the name of the table which contains data for objects of this class. If the ActiveRecord subclass is called MyRecord, the table name will be my_records. Of course you can override this behavior by setting explicitly the value of $table_name in the declaration of your class.

Definition at line 98 of file base.php.

References class_name_to_table_name().

Referenced by ActiveRecord(), delete(), find_all(), find_by_id(), and save().

ActiveRecord::get_foreign_key_name (  )  [private]

Returns the name of the foreign key for this class.

This method returns the name of the column to lookup when considering relations with objects of this class. If the ActiveRecord subclass is called MyRecord, the foreign key name will be my_record_id. Of course you can override this behavior by setting explicitly the value of $foreign_key_name in the declaration of your class.

Definition at line 116 of file base.php.

References class_name_to_foreign_key().

Referenced by has_and_belongs_to_many(), has_many(), and has_one().

ActiveRecord::get_primary_key (  )  [private]

Returns the name of the primary key for this class.

This method returns the name of the primary key in the table bound to this class. By default, ActiveRecord considers as primary key a column named id. Of course you can override this behavior by setting explicitly the value of $primary_key in the declaration of your class.

ActiveRecord::save (  ) 

Requests the receiver to save its data in the bound table.

This method has two distinct effects. If called on an object fetched from the table, it performs an UPDATE SQL statement to update the table data to the new values. If called on an object created programmatically, it performs an INSERT SQL statement, and sets the object's primary key value to the value resulting by the insert.
